html:
HAZARDOUS INGREDIENTS

  • Butane is a gas at ambient temperature and pressure, but is readily liquefied by either pressure and/or refrigeration

  • At atmospheric pressure the boiling point of butane is -0.4 °C

  • Under saturated conditions at 28 °C the saturated pressure is 2.7 x 105 N/m2 and the liquid density is approximately 570 kg/m3

  • Upon release to the atmosphere a volume expansion of 235 times occurs

  • Like LPG, butane leaks result in the formation of large clouds of vapour, and even small quantities of butane vapour in air may form a flammable mixture

  • The limits of flammability of butane are 2% to 8.5% by volume of gas in air with stoichiometric proportions at 3.1% gas in air

  • Butane vapour is heavier than air, and therefore tends to form a cloud along the ground or through drains

  • Under still air conditions, the natural diffusion of accumulated vapour may be slow

  • Butane is a colourless gas which is slightly toxic causing drowsiness, narcosis at high concentration, weakness of muscle; paralysis and simple asphyxiate by starving oxygen from the lungs

  • When heated, butane emits acrid fumes. In its refrigerated or liquefied form (below 0 °C), butane can cause cold burns

  • Butane has a low viscosity, hence it has no lubricating properties and it is more likely to find a leakage path than water or most other petroleum products

  • These facts are significant with respect to the design of plant and have particular relevance to the glands and seals of pumps, compressors and valves

  • Liquid butane has a high coefficient of expansion

  • Therefore equipment containing butane must be provided with adequate ullage and or relief valves to prevent it becoming over-pressured as a result of temperature increases
